channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed for kotaku_com

item.title: Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A Leak Is A Fascinating Look At The Game We Didn‚Äôt Get
item.content:encoded:
I loved Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, but looking at a game in every stage of its development is inevitably going to make you wish a studio had been able to implement every idea it had into the final product. The infamous Game Freak Teraleak from last year has given us a pretty thorough look at Legends: Z-A‚Äôs journey from design doc to finished game, and while it‚Äôs interesting to see these screenshots and pieces of test footage, it also has fans weighing in on Game Freak‚Äôs processes and sharing how they feel about the final product now that they‚Äôve seen how the sausage was made.

YouTuber TurtleBro compiled all his findings in the Teraleak into a feature-length video that goes chronologically through Legends: Z-A‚Äôs development files dating back to 2022, shortly after work on Legends: Arceus had wrapped up. Some files are from so early in the process that Game Freak was using Legends: Arceus‚Äô Irida as a placeholder for the player. These screenshots and videos show some cut content and features, like additional building interiors to explore, being able to use overworld abilities around Lumiose City, and even some additional multiplayer modes that had players throwing Pok√© Balls at one another, dodgeball style. 

Perhaps most surprising in these early builds is a much higher level of environmental detail than we see in the final game. Legends: Z-A was memed to hell and back for its flat-textured buildings, and some of the first pieces of footage TurtleBro shows off include windows and building structures that are much more detailed. In January of 2023, many of these assets were swapped for something similar to the flat ones we have in the game now, and internal notes suggest this downgrade was a ‚Äúburden‚Äù on the team. It‚Äôs here you can see a lot of the game‚Äôs initial ambitions get pulled back, though some things, like the real-time, action-based combat system, started to take shape here, albeit in a more third-person shooter style than the command-based one we have now. By March of that year, the team was on track to deliver the game we got, and morale started to improve.

There‚Äôs one aspect of the development timeline that is kind of fascinating considering 2024 was the first time in quite a few years since there wasn‚Äôt a new Pok√©mon game or expansion: it sounds like Legends: Z-A was feature complete by June 2024, and Game Freak spent around 16 months on polish before it launched the game on October 16, 2025.

TurtleBro speculates that the reason the game‚Äôs visuals were deliberately downgraded was to give the team the year to spend refining the game in order to avoid a massive performance fiasco like the one that surrounded Scarlet and Violet in 2022, though others who viewed the game less charitably suspect Game Freak may have just shelved Legends: Z-A for over a year and moved onto a new project, rather than using that time for meaningful iteration. It‚Äôs unclear, however, as the development details stop at this point; the Teraleak occurred in August, and thus, we don‚Äôt have any more of these design docs that might confirm the team‚Äôs thinking.

Overall, it‚Äôs a fascinating look at how Legends: Z-A went from concept to finished game, and TurtleBro does a great job of comparing images of aspects of the game from early in development to what those aspects look and play like in the actual, released game you can play on your Switch or Switch 2. Check out the full video below:

I do mourn some of the stuff we lost in the development process, but that‚Äôs the risk you take when you look at unfinished work. The video puts the leaks we‚Äôve seen from the upcoming Pok√©mon Wind and Wave games into perspective, serving as a reminder that several of the mechanics and concepts those leaks have revealed may not make it into the final product, either. We‚Äôll know for sure when those games are revealed, which will likely happen for the series‚Äô 30th anniversary next year.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-legends-za-leak-video-old-build-teraleak-window-2000655988
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Malcolm In The Middle Is Returning Because Hollywood Loves Reheating Leftovers
item.content:encoded:
Like everything else that was once popular, the early 2000s Fox TV comedy Malcolm in the Middle is returning in Spring 2026 with stars Frankie Muniz, Bryan Cranston, and Jane Kaczmarek all back to reprise their roles as Malcom, Hal, and Lois, respectively.

On December 29, Disney and Hulu released the first trailer for Life‚Äôs Still Unfair, an upcoming 4-episode Malcom in the Middle miniseries event set around 20 years after the original show, which ran from 2000 to 2006 on Fox. Here‚Äôs the trailer:

And here‚Äôs the official synopsis for the miniseries, which will be exclusively available on Hulu and Disney+:

‚ÄúAfter shielding himself and his daughter from his family for over a decade, Malcolm is dragged back into their orbit when Hal and Lois demand his presence at their 40th anniversary party.‚Äù

As a young pre-teen in the early 2000s, I watched a lot of Malcolm in the Middle during the show‚Äôs original run on TV. But like a lot of people, according to ratings data, I remember my family vaguely checking out around season four. Two years later, the show was canceled due to low ratings. Of course, nostalgia for content from this era is reaching its highest point as people who grew up in that era are now entering their 30s. So Malcolm and his family will soon return to TV (or internet streaming TV) as Hollywood execs and number crunchers hope to squeeze out as much profit and viewership from this reheated revival as they can before they move on to the next somewhat popular TV show or movie from about 20 years ago.

I love leftovers as much as the next guy, but I‚Äôm not sure I need every TV show and movie I grew up with to return for what often ends up being forgettable and tired reunions. Anyway, Malcolm in the Middle: Life‚Äôs Still Unfair will premiere on Hulu and Disney+ on April 10, 2026. Regardless of how I feel about the revival, the show‚Äôs opening song still kicks ass.



https://kotaku.com/malcolm-in-the-middle-revival-life-still-unfair-fox-hulu-trailer-disney-2000655971
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: This Isn‚Äôt Clair Obscur, It‚Äôs A Remake Of An 18-Year-Old Chinese RPG
item.content:encoded:
If you‚Äôre getting Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 vibes from the new trailer for Sword and Fairy 4: Remake, you‚Äôre not alone. Some are pointing to the upcoming RPG as evidence that we‚Äôre about to get lot of copycats trying to ape the 2025 Game of the Year‚Äôs aura, similar to the wave of open-world games that borrowed elements from The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild after that game‚Äôs incredible success. But Sword and Fairy 4: Remake didn‚Äôt spring up out of nowhere, and the series it‚Äôs a part of has a long history of its own.

‚ÄúThis single-player turn-based RPG is reborn in Unreal Engine 5 with the latest technology,‚Äù publisher CubeGame announced on Monday. ‚ÄúSet off on a journey to find the immortals with Tianhe Yun‚Äôs team. In the meantime, a hidden truth that has been sealed for a long time is revealing itself.‚Äù The update was accompanied by a fresh trailer that‚Äôs been turning heads for both its high production values and its flashy turn-based combat.

That last part is the biggest reason why the game‚Äôs been drawing comparisons to Clair Obscur. Like this year‚Äôs hit RPG, Sword and Fairy 4: Remake seems to feature cinematic battle animations with lots of motion blur and slowdown, as well as a command wheel integrated into the scene rather than situated off to the side with the rest of the HUD. The fact that the whole thing is in Unreal Engine 5 adds another level of hyper-realistic sheen reminiscent of Clair Obscur.

But while the internet has a penchant for condensing new stuff down into familiar buzz phrases and using the most popular things as lenses for understanding everything else, Sword and Fairy 4: Remake didn‚Äôt just fall out of a coconut tree. Quoting one site‚Äôs post about the game that called it a ‚ÄúClair Obscur-like,‚Äù The CRPG Book editor Felipe Pepe wrote, ‚ÄúI really hate how games media handles anything out of China. We‚Äôre getting a gorgeous remake of one of their best RPGs ever, but the clown does zero research about it and just goes ‚ÄòI‚Äôm getting a lot of Boss Baby vibes from this‚Ä¶'‚Äù

The original Sword and Fairy 4 looked like this, the second screenshot is the remake, and the third is Expedition 33.

The only bar you have to clear is to recognize shape and colors at this point, and you are failing miserably. My 3-year old cousin can see the similarities https://t.co/HCNNmqtPFV pic.twitter.com/0X9sXdrz9o

‚Äî Dream's Longest Day (@Dreamboum) December 29, 2025

The first The Legend of Sword and Fairy launched for MS-DOS in 1995 and served as an analogue to Final Fantasy rooted in Chinese mythology, but it was never localized outside of East Asia. The most recent entry was 2021‚Äôs Sword and Fairy 7 which abandoned turn-based combat for real-time action and is available on both PC and console. Sword and Fairy 4: Remake, meanwhile, is an update to the 2007 entry which also happens to be available on Steam. It only looks like Clair Obscur to the degree that all turn-based battle RPGs have you similarly watching a static row of fighters enact the commands you select from a menu.

It‚Äôs definitely possible that Sword and Fairy 4: Remake developer UP software has leaned into some of the stylistic RPG design choices we now associate with Clair Obscur in the year since that game blew up (trailers for it were getting fans hyped well before its 2025 release, too). But Clair Obscur owes some of those elements, including its flashy command wheel, to series that came before it, like Persona. As RPG fans have been reminding each other a lot this year, the genre extends well beyond Final Fantasy and a certain modern French riff on the franchise.

Maybe Sword and Fairy 4: Remake will be the latest one to help players continue to expand their turn-based horizons.



https://kotaku.com/clair-obscur-chinese-rpg-sword-fairy-trailer-remake-2000655947
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Fans Call Stranger Things‚Äô Coming Out Scene Sweet, But Corny
item.content:encoded:
Stranger Things is nearly over, with its finale set to premiere on Netflix and in theaters on Wednesday, December 31. Its penultimate episode, ‚ÄúChapter Seven: The Bridge,‚Äù included a scene that was a long time coming: Will (Noah Schnapp) finally coming out to his friends as gay after crushing hard on Mike (Finn Wolfhard). It turns out Will‚Äôs identity isn‚Äôt merely a footnote on his character sheet, but actually ends up playing a pretty major part in the show‚Äôs supernatural horror elements. Now, after years of keeping the truth to himself, Will has finally told all his friends and a few acquaintances who were just kinda around that he is a card-carrying boy liker, and the final scene has received a pretty‚Ä¶mixed response.

So let‚Äôs break it down. Will, who has a psychic connection with series big bad Vecna, is in his feelings after finding out the monster has been using him as a spy since he returned from the  Upside Down in Stranger Things‚Äô first season. He also learns that his connection to this other world created the Upside Down tunnel system that formed underneath Hawkins National Laboratory in season 2, which ‚Äúinfected‚Äù the real world and led to the deaths of many innocent people.

Later in the episode, he tells his mother about Vecna‚Äôs hostile takeover of his mind, and says that the villain sees ‚Äúeverything,‚Äù knowing his secrets and preying on his fears. So in order to beat Vecna, Will says he needs to give him one less secret to wield, and wants his friends and family to know the truth.

Will sits down with a dozen people of varying importance to him and gives, well, a pretty straightforward coming-out confession of the sort that you‚Äôd expect from just about any well-meaning show from the early 2000s. He goes on about how he and all his friends are still the same except for one little detail: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like girls.‚Äù He says that he had a crush on someone he knew wouldn‚Äôt like him back, and that Vecna showed him a manufactured future in which this came between him and his friends, not because of bigotry, but because their overbearing worry for him makes him feel othered to the point of pushing them away. 

As Will starts to cry, his mother and friends, one by one, promise that they‚Äôre not going anywhere and then give him a big group hug. It‚Äôs sweet, but maybe a bit overwrought for modern sensibilities? There‚Äôs a lot to unpack about this moment and how it may or may not land.

This is so fucking absurd I can‚Äôt pic.twitter.com/XkOJQEhjkL

‚Äî Ÿé (@janehopz) December 26, 2025

For some, there‚Äôs just some absurdity to seeing most of the cast of Stranger Things lined up to listen to Will tell everyone he has a crush on another friend in the room, and it also doesn‚Äôt help that much of the cast is just not reacting much at all to the revelation. But I don‚Äôt think that the silliness of the scene is the only issue. 

By 2025, it feels like some queer people may have become a bit jaded toward the traditional coming-out story. It‚Äôs certainly still a universal part of queer experience, but when it‚Äôs often the only lens through which mainstream media views the queer experience, a young twink tearfully telling his bros he‚Äôs ‚Äústill the same‚Äù as he always was probably isn‚Äôt going to land with queer viewers the way it once would have. On the contrary, some queer people don‚Äôt find comfort in stories where a gay character only finds solidarity if they focus on how they are the ‚Äúsame‚Äù as their cishet friends. I‚Äôd rather see stories about that support not being given under the condition of what makes me similar to others, when it should be offered regardless. 

In the case of Stranger Things, I think I‚Äôm willing to offer it some grace because it is ultimately an ‚Äò80s period piece, and even though the Stonewall Riots happened nearly 20 years prior, there was still a lot of work to be done in 1987. So if 16-year-old Will has no other framework to communicate his truth to his friends in the late ‚Äò80s, fair enough. Especially if there are still young people living in small towns like Hawkins who are watching shows like Stranger Things and still at that stage in their lives.

That said, the ‚Äò80s setting does have some fans wondering where the hell this universal acceptance is coming from. Yeah, you could argue the Stranger Things gang has been through so much that they don‚Äôt have time for homophobia, but when has an apocalypse ever been enough to make a bigot admit to the error of their ways? I don‚Äôt know, it‚Äôs an awkward line to walk when you‚Äôre including queer characters in your story. If you show a completely accepting universe, you run the risk of coming off as inauthentic, but if you portray the reality of the queer experience, you will inevitably have the most online armchair consultant calling your work a moral failing to the gays you hope to represent. Everyone‚Äôs got their preferences, but as hokey as the scene might be, I have a hard time viewing it as anything other than well-meaning.

the concept of having like 10 people in a room in the 1980‚Äôs, coming out to them, and not a singular one is homophobic üò≠

no shade is that why erica wasn‚Äôt in the scene üò≠üò≠ https://t.co/qNfAzccG1f

‚Äî Base (@outsoldnation) December 26, 2025

The bigger problem I have with the scene is one many people are having with Stranger Things‚Äô final season, which is that the writing is so straightforward and inelegant that you have to wonder if Netflix is actually telling writers to dumb down their work for the people who are always on their damn phones. Stranger Things has reasonably complex mythology and lore, so I don‚Äôt think anyone who‚Äôs still invested after five seasons needs to have dialogue mashed up and spoonfed to them like they‚Äôre a baby, but that proclivity feels pretty apparent in this scene. At the very least, the polarizing moment has got the shitpost pipeline flowing.

im crine pic.twitter.com/G42e3Cf7jY

‚Äî mike truther (@mikewhpilled) December 27, 2025

will: i don‚Äôt like girls
mike: holy aura
dustin: holy aura
lucas: holy aura
max: holy aura
el: holy aura
everyone else: i‚Äôve seen stranger things
steve: and when i‚Äôm

‚Äî sofia (@miwiseven) December 27, 2025

will: guys the world might be ending but.. i like boys ><
holly: pic.twitter.com/iYiRFg10il

‚Äî emma ‚äπ ‡£™ Ôπèìäù (@elshoneymoon) December 26, 2025

isn't there an apocalypse happening https://t.co/lW6himwIgg

‚Äî jolene of arc (@okaypompeii) December 26, 2025

11 people in this shot and it‚Äôs the 80‚Äôs

statistically at least one of them should be calling him a slur https://t.co/mbjI8M2rsW

‚Äî Maniaüí´ (@NovaMania17) December 26, 2025

will: i dont like girls

Whole gang pulling up to the will byers coming out!! pic.twitter.com/KLqhQA0B5y

Also, holy shit. They took 12 hours to shoot that scene and then another 12 hours for reshoots? Jesus. Anyway, here‚Äôs the superior scene of Robin coming out in season 3 to cleanse your palate.

item.title: Cyberpunk 2077 Company Spins Off Its Steam Competitor
item.content:encoded:
After nearly 20 years of operation, digital video game storefront GOG is no longer a part of Witcher 3 and Cyberpunk 2077 developer CD Projekt Red. It is now fully owned by one of CDPR‚Äôs co-founders who also helped launch GOG.

On December 29, CDPR announced via a press release that its Steam-like storefront, GOG, has been fully acquired by CDPR co-founder Micha≈Ç Kici≈Ñski. As part of the deal, Kici≈Ñski now owns 100 percent of GOG‚Äôs shares after purchasing them for 90 million PLN or about 25 million USD. The deal didn‚Äôt involve the co-founder selling any of his shares in CDPR.

‚ÄúGOG and Micha≈Ç Kici≈Ñski are aligned by a shared belief that games should live forever,‚Äù said GOG managing director Maciej Go≈Çƒôbiewski. ‚ÄúIn a market that‚Äôs getting more crowded, more locked-in, and forgets classic games at an increasing pace, we‚Äôre doubling down on what only GOG does: reviving classics, keeping them playable on modern PCs, and helping great games find their audience over time.‚Äù

Launched in October 2008, GOG (originally known as Good Old Games) was started as a place for retro games to be sold by various publishers and developers. The store offers titles with no DRM and has since expanded greatly, selling new and old games while also starting an ambitious preservation program to help keep dated games running on modern hardware without publisher support.

As to why CDPR is selling GOG now, joint CEO Micha≈Ç Nowakowski says the company has an ‚Äúambitious development roadmap‚Äù and plans to expand the studio‚Äôs franchises, so it made sense to split GOG off and let CDRP focus on its own projects.

‚ÄúFor a long time now, GOG has been operating independently. Now it‚Äôs going into very good hands ‚Äî we are convinced that with the support of Micha≈Ç Kici≈Ñski, one of GOG‚Äôs co-founders, its future will be full of great projects and successes,‚Äú said Nowakowski.

While CDPR will no longer own GOG, it confirmed plans to continue to release its new games on the digital storefront. So, at least for now, it seems like nothing will be changing for players as GOG goes fully independent.



https://kotaku.com/cyberpunk-2077-company-spins-off-its-steam-competitor-2000655953
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Microsoft Office 2024 Is Selling Fast After Dropping to Record Low, One-Time Purchase Installed on Mac of PC (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint)
item.content:encoded:
The trend of most software companies in the last decade has been to switch operations over to a subscription-based model, where you pay monthly for access to the latest features and updates. Microsoft, for example, offers its Office suite through Microsoft 365, which requires an ongoing monthly payment. While this model keeps you up to date with the newest software and app updates, it also means you‚Äôre committing to paying for it forever. There‚Äôs something much more appealing to just paying for a thing once and then owning it, which is why this Microsoft Office deal is very exciting. For a limited time, StackSocial is offering Microsoft Office 2024 Home for both Windows and Mac at a significant discount‚Äîup to 40% off.

The offer includes doesn‚Äôt include the full Microsoft Office suite, just the big three. That‚Äôs Word, Excel, and PowerPoint. You can get the 2024 versions of this software for just $120 for a limited time. That‚Äôs down 20% from $150, saving your $30. If you really need Outlook as well, perhaps operating a small business out of home and are looking for alternatives to Gmail, then you can get the Home & Business bundle which adds on Outlook to the other three. That package is 40% off which brings it from $250 to just $150.

See at StackSocial

One-Time Payment, Lifetime Access

This is the 2024 suite for Microsoft Office applications. They come with a lot of helpful features unique to 2024 and later versions. PowerPoint for instance now lets user record presentations from within the app. You can record voice, video, and closed captions. This is wonderful for teachers uploading courses for online classes as well as really any business presentation that‚Äôd be helpful to be able to reference back to later again and again.

Once you purchase the software, you can immediately download and install it. After completing your order, you will receive an email with your software license keys and download links. The license is tied to your Microsoft Account‚Äînot your actual device‚Äîand is a one-time use code. Be sure to redeem your software within seven days of purchase, as all sales are final once the license is activated. Unredeemed licenses can be returned within seven days for a refund.

If you‚Äôre setting up a new laptop or desktop and want to avoid the hassle of monthly fees, this is what you want over Microsoft 365. For just $120, you can get lifetime access to the 2024 versions of Word, Excel, and PowerPoint. You can add in Outlook for just $30 more. The deal is available to both Windows and Mac users.

See at StackSocial



https://kotaku.com/microsoft-office-2024-is-selling-fast-after-dropping-to-record-low-one-time-purchase-installed-on-mac-of-pc-word-excel-and-powerpoint-2000655757

item.title: Konami Is Turning Silent Hill Into An Annual Franchise
item.content:encoded:
If you really liked the recent Silent Hill 2 remake and this year‚Äôs Silent Hill f and are still craving more foggy survival horror, well, I‚Äôve got some good news for you. Konami has no plans to slow down now and wants to release at least one game a year in the series moving forward. Nothing bad ever happens when a franchise becomes annual, right?

In a recent interview with Famitsu, as translated by Gematsu, Silent Hill series producer Motoi Okamoto talked about the franchise‚Äôs current state and claimed that after releasing two critically acclaimed best-selling Silent Hill games in the last two years, the franchise is ‚Äúback on track.‚Äù And it now sounds like we‚Äôll be returning to the foggy streets of Silent Hill about once a year, assuming everything goes to plan.

‚ÄúIncluding both announced and unannounced [Silent Hill games], we‚Äôre aiming for a release pace of about one title per year,‚Äù Okamoto told Famitsu in its end-of-the-year issue. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure how much of that we‚Äôll be able to realize, but I‚Äôll continue to do my best as producer of the Silent Hill series. Ideally, we‚Äôd like to keep excitement around the Silent Hill series going at all times. We‚Äôre working hard to share new updates, so I‚Äôd appreciate it if you could wait just a little longer.‚Äù

Before the excellent Silent Hill 2 remake in October 2024, the survival horror franchise had fallen into disrepair, with very few new entries, and the few games that did arrive were generally disappointing. Remember 2023‚Äôs Silent Hill Accession, that interactive livestream‚Ä¶thing? Bleh. And before that, the last real Silent Hill game we got was 2012‚Äôs Downpour, a forgettable and bland horror game that basically put the series on ice for a decade.

Now, in 2025 and after two great games, Silent Hill is in a great place, and while I‚Äôm nervous about it becoming an annual franchise, I think Silent Hill 2 and f show a path forward that could make this work. If different studios are brought in and allowed to play around with the franchise‚Äôs past as well as take it in new directions, we might be in for a golden age of Silent Hill games. And that seems to be Konami‚Äôs plan, with a Silent Hill 1 remake in development as well as a mysterious project, Townfall. Or maybe the franchise is about to fly off the rails again.



https://kotaku.com/konami-is-turning-silent-hill-into-an-annual-franchise-remake-townfall-2000655940
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot
